repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fix #3047. CPython added PyMem_RawCalloc and PyMem_Calloc in version 3.5. I did not
in include a version guard for 3.4 because PyObject_Calloc was also
added in 3.5 but it's already in this file without a version guard.

I updated comments for other functions to reflect PyMem_Calloc but not
PyMem_RawCalloc to match comments' currently only referencing
PyMem_Malloc and friends.

I did not modify Cython/Utility/ModuleSetupCode.c, where
PyMem_RawMalloc, PyMem_RawRealloc, and PyMem_RawFree are #defined for
Python 3.3 because (a) I couldn't figure out where these were being used
and (b) they're defined to their non-raw versions, which strikes me as
dangerous since the Raw versions allow use without the GIL but the
non-Raw versions do not.

Finally, I updated the tests in cpython_capi.pyx. I'm never sure when
compilers decide code is dead and just ignore it, so I tried actually to
write to the memory and return data from it. I can't figure out how to
run Cython's tests, so... fingers crossed.

comment_data.body:
CI failed, and I think this is the relevant bit:

```python-traceback
======================================================================
ERROR: runTest (__main__.CythonRunTestCase)
compiling (c/cy2) and running cpython_capi
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "runtests.py", line 1278, in run
    ext_so_path = self.runCompileTest()
  File "runtests.py", line 962, in runCompileTest
    self.test_directory, self.expect_errors, self.expect_warnings, self.annotate)
  File "runtests.py", line 1202, in compile
    self._match_output(expected_errors, errors, tostderr)
  File "runtests.py", line 1251, in _match_output
    self.assertEqual(None, unexpected)
AssertionError: None != '24:57: starred expression is not allowed here'

----------------------------------------------------------------------
```

I'm guessing that this is not a legitimate way to pass a pointer in Cython. I selected "allow edits from maintainers", so no need to wait for me to fix it if a maintainer wants to just cut and paste that helper function in the right places and be done with it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,18 +5,36 @@ from cpython cimport mem
 from cpython.pystate cimport PyGILState_Ensure, PyGILState_Release, PyGILState_STATE
 
 
+cdef short _assert_calloc(short * s, int n):

comment_data.body: Actually, the bug is here. you probably meant to say `s[0]`. But I'd advise against that, because you're only just declaring it right in the same statement. Just use `sizeof(short)` (also below).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,18 +5,36 @@ from cpython cimport mem
 from cpython.pystate cimport PyGILState_Ensure, PyGILState_Release, PyGILState_STATE
 
 
+cdef short _assert_calloc(short * s, int n):
+    """Assert array ``s`` of length ``n`` is zero and return 3."""
+    s[0] += 1
+    s[n - 1] += 3
+    assert not s[0] and not s[n - 1]
+    for i in range(1, n - 1):
+        assert not s[i]
+    return s[n - 1]
+
+
 def test_pymalloc():
     """
     >>> test_pymalloc()
     3
     """
+    cdef short i
+    cdef short* s = <short*> mem.PyMem_Calloc(10, sizeof(*s))

comment_data.body:
In order to avoid calling into code that isn't nogil-safe, what about
```
if cpython.version.PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x03050000:
    with nogil:
        … mem.PyMem_RawCalloc(…)
else:
    … mem.PyMem_Calloc(…)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -30,16 +48,25 @@ def test_pymalloc_raw():
     >>> test_pymalloc_raw()
     3
     """
+    cdef short i
+    cdef short* s
     cdef char* m
     cdef char* m2 = NULL
     with nogil:
+        s = <short*> mem.PyMem_RawCalloc(10, sizeof(*s))

comment_data.body: Should be resolved by 52677e2—un-resolve this thread if it isn't.

comment_data.body: I'm not clear on what the oldest version of CPython that Cython supports is. https://cython.org/ says 3.3 is the oldest, presumably referring to Cython 0.28.5. The closest thing I could find to a statement about CPython version support for new features (which this PR presumably is) is https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2800#issuecomment-466781420. Do you expect this PR to be merged into Cython 3.0, which maybe will support CPython 3.4, or into Cython 3.1, which maybe will support CPython ≥3.5? If the latter, there's no need for the version guard. If the former, the version guard would need to go around already-existing uses of `PyObject_Calloc`, which don't have a version guard.

     with nogil:
+        s = <short*> mem.PyMem_RawCalloc(10, sizeof(*s))

comment_data.body: The guard is only meant for the test. And I would see this as a feature for 3.0, although we made some exceptions like this for 0.29.x already, so I might end up cherry picking it over to the current release branch.

+        if not s:
+            raise MemoryError()
+        try:
+            i = _assert_calloc(s, 10)
+        finally:
+            mem.PyMem_Free(s)

comment_data.body:
In order to be able to call this function from a `nogil` section _and_ raise exceptions from it, it needs to be declared:
```cython
cdef short _assert_calloc(short* s, int n) except -1 with gil:
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,18 +5,36 @@ from cpython cimport mem
 from cpython.pystate cimport PyGILState_Ensure, PyGILState_Release, PyGILState_STATE
 
 
+cdef short _assert_calloc(short * s, int n):

comment_data.body: Fixed it myself, since I was at it anyway.

comment_data.body:
Both [`PyMem_Calloc`](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/memory.html#c.PyMem_Calloc) and [`PyMem_RawCalloc`](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/memory.html#c.PyMem_RawCalloc) were added in 3.5, so do you actually mean the following?

```diff
diff --git a/tests/run/cpython_capi.pyx b/tests/run/cpython_capi.pyx
index 6d50352b0..f6c57873e 100644
--- a/tests/run/cpython_capi.pyx
+++ b/tests/run/cpython_capi.pyx
@@ -1,6 +1,7 @@
 # mode: run
 # tag: c-api
 
+from cpython.version cimport PY_VERSION_HEX
 from cpython cimport mem
 from cpython.pystate cimport PyGILState_Ensure, PyGILState_Release, PyGILState_STATE
 
@@ -21,13 +22,16 @@ def test_pymalloc():
     3
     """
     cdef short i
-    cdef short* s = <short*> mem.PyMem_Calloc(10, sizeof(short))
-    if not s:
-        raise MemoryError()
-    try:
-        i = _assert_calloc(s, 10)
-    finally:
-        mem.PyMem_Free(s)
+    if PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x03050000:
+        cdef short* s = <short*> mem.PyMem_Calloc(10, sizeof(short))
+        if not s:
+            raise MemoryError()
+        try:
+            i = _assert_calloc(s, 10)
+        finally:
+            mem.PyMem_Free(s)
+    else:
+        i = 3
     cdef char* m2
     cdef char* m = <char*> mem.PyMem_Malloc(20)
     assert m
@@ -53,13 +57,16 @@ def test_pymalloc_raw():
     cdef char* m
     cdef char* m2 = NULL
     with nogil:
-        s = <short*> mem.PyMem_RawCalloc(10, sizeof(short))
-        if not s:
-            raise MemoryError()
-        try:
-            i = _assert_calloc(s, 10)
-        finally:
-            mem.PyMem_RawFree(s)
+        if PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x03050000:
+            s = <short*> mem.PyMem_RawCalloc(10, sizeof(short))
+            if not s:
+                raise MemoryError()
+            try:
+                i = _assert_calloc(s, 10)
+            finally:
+                mem.PyMem_RawFree(s)
+        else:
+            i = 3
         m = <char*> mem.PyMem_RawMalloc(20)
         if not m:
             raise MemoryError()
```

comment_data.body: Tests appear to be passing for CPython ≥3.5, except unrelated failures for CPython 3.5 on the C++ backend.

commit.message:
Fix #3047: Add PyMem_(Raw)Calloc to cpython.mem

CPython added PyMem_RawCalloc and PyMem_Calloc in version 3.5. I did not
in include a version guard for 3.4 because PyObject_Calloc was also
added in 3.5 but it's already in this file without a version guard.

I updated comments for other functions to reflect PyMem_Calloc but not
PyMem_RawCalloc to match comments' currently only referencing
PyMem_Malloc and friends.

I did not modify Cython/Utility/ModuleSetupCode.c, where
PyMem_RawMalloc, PyMem_RawRealloc, and PyMem_RawFree are #defined for
Python 3.3 because (a) I couldn't figure out where these were being used
and (b) they're defined to their non-raw versions, which strikes me as
dangerous since the Raw versions allow use without the GIL but the
non-Raw versions do not.

Finally, I updated the tests in cpython_capi.pyx. I'm never sure when
compilers decide code is dead and just ignore it, so I tried actually to
write to the memory and return data from it. I can't figure out how to
run Cython's tests, so... fingers crossed.

Fix tests

1. Replace sizeof(*s) with sizeof(short) per
https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3050/files#r307708557 (and
besides, Cython dereferences pointers as s[0], not *s).

2. Replace free(m) with free(s)—this typo would have freed the address
in the uninitialized stack variable m rather than the initialized
variable s. This was blatently undefined behavior.

Use PyMem_RawFree with PyMem_RawCalloc

commit.message:
Fix failing test assertion

The array entries couldn't be zero right after setting them to 1 and 3.
Reordering the lines of code should make the assertion work now.

Fix failing test assertion

The array entries couldn't be zero right after setting them to 1 and 3.
Reordering the lines of code should make the assertion work now.

commit.message:
TEST: Skip `run.cpython-capi` test on Python < 3.5

Python has no `PyMem_Calloc` before version 3.5, so the `run.cpython_capi` test
doesn't work. This change suggested by @da-woods at
https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3050#issuecomment-640013866
